ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Paper reading skills
Human genetics, how to evaluate and interpret the results
I learned how to think more critically about genetics based experiments, as well as improved my ability to write about them. I also found the course inspiring and motivating
I learned a lot about techniques within genetics in this course, that felt very useful.
Basic concepts in genetics. Interpreting modern genetic analyses (GWAS, HiC, ChIP, etc)
A better idea of the thought process of a genetics researcher.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Focus is very medical and animal-oriented -- I don't feel that it covered the full scope of genetic model systems and genetic techniques. Papers were not always relevant to lecture material. Topics were taught in a strange order -- It was a little odd that we were taught genomics and more modern sequencing approaches before we were taught mosaic analysis and other much older techniques. Discussion sections did not evaluate or even discuss the papers very much.
Different topics with the development history involved to provide a clear logic

weakness - the order of the lectures didn't seem to make sense; some of the historical papers and lectures was all on information it seems like most people would have picked up in undergrad; teaching more about current applications of genetics would have been more helpful

The discussion section was way too big, and made it difficult for all to participate. Also, I wish there was a bigger focus on more modern experiments as opposed to the classic experiments from the 90s.

I have learned most of the traditional genetics, such as forward genetic screen, epistasis analysis, transgenic animal and mosaic analysis in college. Therefore learning these things again seems a little repetitive. I would suggest introducing more about GWAS and human genetics. Also, the synopsis before every discussion is a lot of work, yet it is not very helpful in improving our understanding of the paper, and we seldom receive feedback regarding the synopsis.
I very much liked the take home questions in this course.
Strength, multiple faculty for one course.

I think the professors had very different styles of lecturing and discussing. Especially for discussing I think it would be nice to find a consensus on how it is going to be so that we can get the most out of every session.
The sections with the professors were always extremely rewarding. The continuity of lectures between professors wasn't always the best, and some problem sets (and its grading) didn't seem clear.
Weaknesses: A couple of faculties were deeply engaged with the students and the course, while some faculties weren't.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course if the student does not have very much background in genetics and if they are very interested in medical genetics.
It is helpful to have a taste of genetics for those who are not majoring in this
Yes, I think the class is very useful and interesting and helps to yield a good background in genetics for graduate students.
Yes
Yes, I found this class very interesting.

This course wasn't an amazing course. The discussion sections with the professors were really great but lecture and psets were generally not clear or intellectually rewarding. I personally didn't get much out of the course over the intro Genetics course in MCDB.
Yes
